lines.text: Captain... what language is this?
It's Latin. "Mihi libertas necessest."
"I must have liberty."
[after the men finish eating the giant crab]
That's the best crab I ever cooked.
We'd be more impressed, Mr. Spilitt, if you'd put it in the pot by yourself.
[finding an unconscious Elena on the shore]
She's beautiful.
Better than that, she's alive.
I ran away from a battle. I've been running ever since. I got caught running away.
Son, your whole Union Army's been running from mine for the last three years. Now we're running away from you. You needn't feel special about it.
Captain, why don't we turn this island into a democracy and elect a leader? One who won't keep escaping to places which need escaping from.
Because all of us here are still at war, and I just happen to be the ranking officer.
I'm going to ask Captain Harding to marry us.
That'd be wonderful, if he were only a minister, but he's not.
He's a captain, and captains can marry people at sea.
He's a land captain, not a sea captain.
Well, we're on land, aren't we?

[to Spilitt]
You supply the ink. The soldiers supply the blood.
Now Captain Harding, aren't you ready to dance with the devil now?
Show me the pumps and the power to raise that ship, and then you'll have seven new waltz partners.
[last lines]

We deeply regretted we could not save the life of the man who had saved ours. A man who dedicated himself to ending strife among men. And when we returned to civilization, we all pledged ourselves to working for a peaceful and bountiful world, as Captain Nemo would have it.
[first lines]
All right, now get down.
This was just the beginning. We escaped, but only into the clutches of the greatest storm in American History.
Below us, when we could still see through the patches of angry clouds, were smashed cities and forests torn up by their roots.

Then finally, the earth disappeared from our view. We were prisoners of the wind, helpless in the storm's mighty grip. And we wondered, how much longer we'd remain aloft. Would we ever set foot on the earth again?
What I did was in the name of peace. Your war, like all wars, glories in devastation and death.
Well, my war will set men free.
